edge.notes: WebVR content requires a Windows Mixed Reality headset or the Windows Mixed Reality Portal Simulator.

firefox.notes: Windows support was enabled in Firefox 55.
macOS support was enabled in Firefox 64.

chrome.notes: Before Chrome 70, this feature was only supported in macOS.  In Chrome 70, support was added for Windows 10. Linux support is not enabled by default.
In Linux and versions of Windows earlier than 10, this flag must be enabled.

edge.notes: Supported by default only on macOS and Windows 10. Linux support is not enabled by default.
In Linux and versions of Windows earlier than 10, this flag must be enabled.

opera.notes: Before Opera 57, this feature was only supported in macOS.  In Opera 57, support was added for Windows 10. Linux support is not enabled by default.
In Linux and versions of Windows earlier than 10, this flag must be enabled.

firefox.notes: Returns a fixed timestamp as a privacy measure - 20181001000000.

firefox_android.notes: Returns a fixed timestamp as a privacy measure - 20181001000000.

chrome.notes: Not supported on macOS, see bug 1144920.

edge.notes: Not supported on macOS, see bug 1144920.

opera.notes: Not supported on macOS, see bug 1144920.

opera.notes: Not supported on macOS, see bug 1144920.

firefox_android.notes: The Network API is enabled by default. Can be disabled using the dom.netinfo.enabled preference.

firefox.notes: Before Firefox 8, navigator.cookieEnabled would report the wrong result if a site exception was in place for the page on which the check was performed. This has been fixed.

firefox_android.notes: Before Firefox 8, navigator.cookieEnabled would report the wrong result if a site exception was in place for the page on which the check was performed. This has been fixed.

ie.notes: navigator.cookieEnabled returns true even if the browser is set to block cookies (for example, if the page is in the Restricted sites security zone).

firefox.notes: Before Firefox 32, navigator.doNotTrack would report values of yes and no rather than 1 and 0.

firefox_android.notes: Before Firefox 32, navigator.doNotTrack would report values of yes and no rather than 1 and 0.

ie.notes: For IE11 and subsequent versions, use window.doNotTrack

chrome.notes: Only supported on Windows. Resolves with an empty array on other platforms.
Always resolves with an empty array.

edge.notes: Only supported on Windows. Resolves with an empty array on other platforms.
Always resolves with an empty array.

opera.notes: Only supported on Windows. Resolves with an empty array on other platforms.
Always resolves with an empty array.

chrome.notes: Available on all platforms behind a flag, but currently only works on desktop in an experimental version of Chrome (other builds won't return any devices when Navigator.getVRDisplays() is invoked).

chrome_android.notes: Currently supported only by Google Daydream.

firefox.notes: Windows support was enabled in Firefox 55.
macOS support was enabled in Firefox 64.

samsunginternet_android.notes: Currently supported only by Google Daydream.

firefox.notes: Before Firefox 4, this property's value was also part of the user agent string, as reported by navigator.userAgent. Starting in Firefox 5, this property's value is based on the value of the Accept-Language HTTP header.

chrome.notes: Before Chrome 65, navigator.languages[0] is not guaranteed to equal navigator.language.

chrome_android.notes: Before Chrome 65, navigator.languages[0] is not guaranteed to equal navigator.language.

firefox.notes: In Firefox, the navigator.languages property's value is taken from the intl.accept_languages preference.

firefox_android.notes: In Firefox, the navigator.languages property's value is taken from the intl.accept_languages preference.

webview_android.notes: Before version 65, navigator.languages[0] is not guaranteed to equal navigator.language.

chrome.notes: Earlier versions of Chrome incorrectly return true when a tab is first opened, but it starts reporting the correct connectivity status after the first network event. Windows: 11, macOS: 14, Chrome OS: 13, Linux: Always returns true. For history, see crbug.com/7469.

firefox.notes: Since Firefox 4 the browser returns true when 'Work Offline' mode is disabled and false when it is enabled, regardless of actual connectivity. Since Firefox 41, on OS X and Windows, the returned values follow the actual network connectivity, unless 'Work offline' mode is selected (where it will always return false).

ie.notes: in Internet Explorer 8 'online' and 'offline' events are raised on the document.body; under IE 9 they are raised on both document.body and window.

opera.notes: From Opera 11.1 until Opera 12.1, the browser returns true when 'Work Offline' mode is disabled and false when it is enabled, regardless of actual connectivity.

opera_android.notes: From Opera 11.1 until Opera 12.1, the browser returns true when 'Work Offline' mode is disabled and false when it is enabled, regardless of actual connectivity.

webview_android.notes: Can incorrectly return true, see bug 811122.

firefox.notes: The preference "general.oscpu.override" can be used to set a value to be returned instead of the true CPU description. The preference setting is ignored for calls made by privileged code, which continue to get the actual CPU description.

firefox_android.notes: The preference "general.oscpu.override" can be used to set a value to be returned instead of the true CPU description. The preference setting is ignored for calls made by privileged code, which continue to get the actual CPU description.

notes: Before Firefox 69, platform would report running on a 32-bit CPU if running the 32-bit version of Firefox on a 64-bit system.
You can override the value returned by platform by setting the preference general.platform.override to the string you wish to be returned instead.
Allowed schemes include mailto, mms, nntp, rtsp, and webcal. Custom protocols must be prefixed with web+.
From Chrome 77, the URL parameter only accepts http or https URLs.
The obsolete title parameter is required.
Allowed schemes include mailto, mms, nntp, rtsp, and webcal. Custom protocols must be prefixed with web+.
The obsolete title parameter is required.
The spec requires that the passed supportedConfigurations option contain at least one of audioCapabilities or videoCapabilities, and that said parameters include a codec string.
The function does not exist in insecure contexts. This was not enforced until Chrome 58.
The spec requires that the passed supportedConfigurations option contain at least one of audioCapabilities or videoCapabilities, and that said parameters include a codec string.
The function does not exist in insecure contexts. This was not enforced until Chrome 58.
Starting in Firefox 55, if neither audioCapabilities nor videoCapabilities is specified in supportedConfigurations, a warning is output to the web console.

In addition, starting in Firefox 55, if in supportedConfigurations, either audioCapabilities's or videoCapabilities's contentType value doesn't specify a "codecs" substring to define allowed codecs within the media wrapper, a warning is output to the web console. See note below table for example and correction.
In the future, if neither audioCapabilities nor videoCapabilities is specified in the supportedConfigurations, a NotSupported exception will be thrown.
Starting in Firefox 55, if neither audioCapabilities nor videoCapabilities is specified in supportedConfigurations, a warning is output to the web console.

In addition, starting in Firefox 55, if in supportedConfigurations, either audioCapabilities's or videoCapabilities's contentType value doesn't specify a "codecs" substring to define allowed codecs within the media wrapper, a warning is output to the web console. See note below table for example and correction.
In the future, if neither audioCapabilities nor videoCapabilities is specified in the supportedConfigurations, a NotSupported exception will be thrown.
The spec requires that the passed supportedConfigurations option contain at least one of audioCapabilities or videoCapabilities, and that said parameters include a codec string.
The function does not exist in insecure contexts. This was not enforced until Opera 45.

chrome.notes: Starting in Chrome 59, this method cannot send a Blob whose type is not CORS safelisted. This is a temporary change until a mitigation can be found for the security issues that this creates. For more information see Chrome bug 720283.

webview_android.notes: Starting in Chrome 59, this method cannot send a Blob whose type is not CORS safelisted. This is a temporary change until a mitigation can be found for the security issues that this creates. For more information see Chrome bug 720283.

firefox.notes: Extended Support Releases (ESR) before Firefox 78 ESR do not support service workers and the Push API.

webview_android.notes: WebView exposes navigator.usb, but does not support WebUSB. See Chromium bug 933055.

notes: Beginning in Chrome 55, this is not supported in cross-origin iframes.
Beginning in Chrome 60, this method requires a user gesture. Otherwise it returns false.
Until Firefox 26 included, when the vibration pattern was too long or any of its elements too large, Firefox threw an exception instead of returning false (bug 884935).
From Firefox 32 onwards, when the vibration pattern is too long or any of its elements too large, it returns true but truncates the pattern (bug 1014581).
Beginning in Firefox 72, this is not supported in cross-origin iframes.

firefox_android.notes: Vibration is disabled. If the window is visible, then navigator.vibrate() returns true, but no vibration takes place (regardless of hardware support). See bug 1591113.

notes: Until Firefox 26 included, when the vibration pattern was too long or any of its elements too large, Firefox threw an exception instead of returning false (bug 884935).
From Firefox 32 onwards, when the vibration pattern is too long or any of its elements too large, it returns true but truncates the pattern (bug 1014581).
